content.user_title: Operate Local Kubernetes Clusters with Minikube
content.value_statement: Running Kubernetes locally is complex with cluster setup, networking, and image management challenges. This skill provides quick reference commands for Minikube and kubectl to streamline local development workflows.
actual_capabilities: Start and configure Minikube clusters with specific resource allocations
Enable and manage Minikube addons like ingress and metrics-server
Execute kubectl commands for resource management and debugging
Load local Docker images into Minikube clusters
Configure service access methods including NodePort, LoadBalancer, and port forwarding
Generate Kubernetes manifest files for deployments, services, and ingress
limitations: Requires Minikube and kubectl to be installed on the local system
Does not cover cloud-based Kubernetes deployments or production configurations
Focuses on single-node local clusters, not multi-node setups
Does not include advanced topics like Helm charts or operators

use_cases.title: Local Application Development

use_cases.title: Learning Kubernetes Fundamentals

use_cases.title: Debugging Kubernetes Issues
use_cases.description: Engineers can reproduce and debug production issues locally with full access to logs, events, and cluster state.

prompt_templates.title: Start a Minikube Cluster
prompt_templates.prompt: Start a Minikube cluster with 8GB memory and 4 CPUs, then enable the ingress addon

prompt_templates.scenario: Testing a newly built Docker image in Kubernetes

output_examples.input: Start a Minikube cluster with 8GB memory and enable ingress
output_examples.output:
Starting cluster with:
  minikube start --memory=8192 --cpus=4

Cluster started successfully. Enabling ingress addon:
  minikube addons enable ingress

Ingress addon enabled. Your cluster is ready for local development.

output_examples.input: Why is my pod failing to start?
output_examples.output:
Checking pod status and events:

The pod shows ImagePullBackOff error. The image my-app:latest is not found in Minikube's Docker registry.

To fix this:
1. Point Docker to Minikube: eval $(minikube docker-env)
2. Rebuild your image: docker build -t my-app:latest .
3. Update your deployment to use imagePullPolicy: Never
4. Reapply: kubectl apply -f deployment.yaml

output_examples.input: How do I access my service from my browser?
output_examples.output:
Your service is type NodePort. Access it using:
  minikube service my-service --url

This returns: http://192.168.49.2:30123

Open this URL in your browser to access your application.

best_practices: Always use imagePullPolicy Never for local Docker images to avoid pulling from remote registries
Enable metrics-server addon before using kubectl top commands for resource monitoring
Run minikube tunnel in a separate terminal when using LoadBalancer services for stable access
anti_patterns: Do not use minikube delete to stop a cluster temporarily, use minikube stop to preserve state
Avoid building images outside Minikube Docker context without eval $(minikube docker-env) first
Do not commit manifests with imagePullPolicy Never to production repositories, it is for local use only

faq.question: How do I use local Docker images in Minikube?
faq.answer: Run eval $(minikube docker-env) to point your Docker CLI to Minikube's Docker daemon. Then build your image and set imagePullPolicy Never in your deployment manifest.

faq.question: Why can I not access my service from localhost?
faq.answer: Minikube runs in a VM or container with its own IP. Use minikube service <name> --url to get the accessible URL, or run minikube tunnel for LoadBalancer services.

faq.question: How do I debug a pod that keeps crashing?
faq.answer: Use kubectl describe pod <name> to check events, and kubectl logs <name> --previous to see logs from the crashed container before it restarted.

faq.question: What addons should I enable for local development?
faq.answer: Enable ingress for external access, metrics-server for resource monitoring with kubectl top, and storage-provisioner for persistent volume claims.

faq.question: How do I reset my Minikube environment completely?
faq.answer: Run minikube delete to remove the cluster entirely, then minikube start to create a fresh cluster. This removes all deployed resources and configurations.

faq.question: Can I run multiple Minikube clusters simultaneously?
faq.answer: Yes, use minikube start -p cluster-name to create named clusters. Switch between them using minikube profile cluster-name or kubectl config use-context.
